revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Ozeki]] (link changed to [[Ōzeki]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
The following are the events in professional [[sumo]] during 2000.
==Tournaments== *Hatsu [[honbasho|basho]], [[Ryogoku Kokugikan]], [[Tokyo]], 9 – 23 January *Haru basho, [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Osaka]], 12 – 26 March *Natsu basho, Ryogoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 7 – 21 May *Nagoya basho, [[Aichi Prefectural Gymnasium]], [[Nagoya]], 9 – 23 July *Aki basho, Ryogoku Kokugikan, Tokyo, 3 – 17 September *Kyushu basho, [[Fukuoka Kokusai Center|Fukuoka International Centre]], [[Kyushu]], 5 – 19 November
==News==
===January=== *At the Hatsu basho in [[Tokyo]], [[sekiwake]] [[Musoyama]] wins his first top [[makuuchi]] division [[yusho]] or tournament championship with a 13–2 record, finishing one win ahead of [[Fujishima stable (2010)|Musashigawa]] stablemate [[Miyabiyama]], and [[yokozuna (sumo)|yokozuna]] [[Takanohana]]. He wins Technique and Outstanding Performance [[sansho (sumo)|Prizes]] (the latter shared with Miyabiyama). The Fighting Spirit Award is given jointly to [[Kyokutenho]] and [[Takanowaka]]. Yokozuna [[Musashimaru]] pulls out through injury. It is the first time he has missed any bouts in his career and it brings to an end a record run of 55 consecutive tournaments with a majority of wins. Former komusubi [[Oginishiki]] wins his second [[juryo]] division championship in a row.
===February=== * Former maegashira [[Kushimaumi]] branches out from [[Dewanoumi stable]] to open his own [[Tagonoura stable (2000)|Tagonoura stable]]. * [[Kise stable]] shuts down as its stablemaster, former maegashira [[Kiyonomori Masao|Kiyonomori]], is approaching the mandatory retirement age of 65.
===March=== *The sumo world has to deal with several allegations of [[match-fixing in professional sumo|match-fixing]] - Hawaiian former wrestler [[Takamio]] tells the ''[[Shukan Post]]'' that he helped yokozuna [[Akebono Taro|Akebono]] fix matches, ex-[[komusubi]] [[Itai Keisuke|Itai]] makes similar allegations in a series of articles, and [[Shikinohana]] says current members of the [[Sumo Association]]'s hierarchy also engaged in the practice when they were active wrestlers decades ago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/14/sports/wrestlers-try-to-fight-on-amid-swirl-of-boutrigging-stories.html|title=Wrestlers Try to Fight On Amid Swirl of Bout-Rigging Stories|last=Kattoulas|first=Velisarios|date=14 March 2000|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> *The [[Osaka]] tournament has a surprise winner: 32-year-old [[maegashira]] [[Takatoriki]], who was on the brink of demotion but pulls off a stunning 13–2 score. He also wins the Outstanding Performance Award, and a record tenth Fighting Spirit Prize. Musoyama finishes runner-up alongside Akebono and earns promotion to [[Ōzeki|ozeki]]. He also receives his fourth Technique Prize. Miyabiyama gets a share of the Fighting Spirit Prize. Takanohana's elder brother and fellow yokozuna [[Wakanohana Masaru|Wakanohana]] announces his retirement at the age of 29, after failing to recover from a leg injury sustained in the previous September tournament. He proved unable to add to his five career championships in his brief yokozuna career. [[Tochinohana]] wins the juryo yusho.
===April=== *27: The [[Sumo Association]] award Wakanohana a bonus of 70 million yen for his services to sumo. *30: 4500 spectators attend a training session for all the top rikishi at the Kokugikan, which is open to the public for the first time.
===May=== [[File:Sumo May09 Kaio.jpg|thumb|right|[[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaio]] won his first yusho and promotion to ozeki in 2000.]] *For the third tournament in a row, a rikishi below the rank of ozeki takes the championship: this time it is [[komusubi]] [[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaio]] with a 14–1 record. He receives his ninth Outstanding Performance Prize, and fifth Fighting Spirit Award. Yokozuna Takanohana and Akebono finish one win behind on 13–2. Musoyama misses his debut ozeki tournament through injury. Miyabiyama joins him at the rank after posting his second consecutive 11–4 record, but the decision to promote him is (unusually) not unanimous. He also gets a share of the Shukun-sho. He replaces veteran [[Takanonami]], who is demoted from ozeki for the second time. Tochinohana, in his top division debut, scores 12 and receives the Fighting Spirit and Technique Prizes. A record eight [[sekitori]] miss the tournament, the most since the six tournaments per year schedule was introduced in 1958. [[Wakanosato]], recuperating from injury, wins the juryo championship. Former maegashira [[Ganyū Kenji|Ganyū]] retires.
===July=== *In [[Nagoya]], Akebono wins his first yusho since 1997, finishing one win ahead of sekiwake [[Tochiazuma Daisuke|Tochiazuma]] with a 13–2 score. Tochiazuma receives the Technique Prize. Takanohana pulls out after injuring his elbow. Musoyama can only manage four wins and is demoted from ozeki. Kaio by contrast follows up his yusho in May with a fine 11–4 record and is finally promoted to ozeki at the age of 28. He also receives a record-equalling tenth Outstanding Performance Prize. The Fighting Spirit Award is shared between newcomers [[Takamisakari]] and [[Aminishiki]], who each score ten. American [[Sentoryu]] also gets a winning score in his debut top division tournament. Wakanosato wins his second juryo yusho in a row. The [[makushita]] division championship is won by [[Asashoryu]] with a perfect 7–0 record.
===August=== *[[Tatsutagawa stable]] shuts down as its stablemaster, former sekiwake [[Aonosato Sakari|Aonosato]], is approaching the mandatory retirement age. Its wrestlers, including sekitori [[Jumonji Tomokazu|Jumonji]], [[Shikishima Katsumori|Shikishima]] and [[Toyozakura]], move to [[Michinoku stable]].
===September=== *Having suffered from injuries and been looking below par all year, Musashimaru dominates the Aki basho, losing only on the final day to win his eighth championship with a 14–1 score. Akebono finishes runner-up on 13–2. Takanohana sits the tournament out. Musoyama regains his ozeki rank by winning ten bouts, meaning there will be five ozeki in November. Tochinohana and [[Hayateumi]] share the Technique Prize. Wakanosato gets the Fighting Spirit Award on his return to makuuchi. [[Kotomitsuki]] wins the juryo championship. Popular top division veterans [[Kotonishiki]] and [[Mitoizumi]], now in juryo, both announce their retirements. Also retiring are former maegashira [[Kitakachidoki]] (meaning there are no longer any sekitori from [[Hokkaido]]) and [[Ohinode]]. *23: Wakanohana's retirement ceremony ([[danpatsu-shiki]]) takes place at the Kokugikan. Accompanying him in his final yokozuna [[dohyo-iri]] are his fellow grand champions Akebono and Takanohana.
===November=== *In [[Kyushu]], Akebono wins his second yusho of the year, and eleventh overall, with a fine 14–1 record. This means he has more wins this year than any other wrestler. He finishes one win ahead of newcomer Kotomitsuki, who wins all three [[sansho (sumo)|special prizes]]. Wakanosato also receives his first Outstanding Performance Prize. [[Kinkaiyama]] wins his third juryo championship. Ex maegashira [[Dewaarashi]] retires. *18: The former Wakanohana announces he is giving up his elder position in the Sumo Association to become a TV [[tarento]].
==Deaths== *14 Jan: Onaruto Oyakata, former maegashira [[Yoshinotani]], aged 50.
==See also== *[[Glossary of sumo terms]] *[[List of past sumo wrestlers]] *[[List of years in sumo]] *[[List of yokozuna]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Years in sumo}}

French [[intertitles]] | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''A Gentleman of the Ring''''' (French:'''''Chouchou poids plume''''') is a 1926 French [[silent film|silent]] [[sports film]] directed by [[Gaston Ravel]] and starring [[André Roanne]], [[Olga Day]] and [[André Lefaur]].Powrie & Rebillard p.33 It was [[A Gentleman of the Ring (1932 film)|remade as a sound film]] in 1932. It was released in Britain in 1927 by [[Stoll Pictures]]. The film's sets were designed by [[Tony Lekain]]. ==Cast== * [[ André Roanne ]] as Chouchou * [[Olga Day]] as Diana Benson * [[André Lefaur]] as Le comte Brodelet de Surville * [[Chriss Lee]] as Jim * [[Juanita de Frézia]] as La comtesse de Surville * [[Simone Mareuil]] as Moineau * [[Reine Derns]] as La femme du manager * [[Pionnier (actor)|Pionnier]] as Battling Tatave * [[Frank Hall (actor)|Frank Hall]] as Le sparring-partner * [[Raymond Lauzerte]] as Une compagne de fête * [[Frédérique Soule]] as Une compagne de fête * [[Pierrette Raff]] as Une compagne de fête * [[Nicolas Redelsperger]] as Une compagne de fête * [[Bernhard (actor)|Bernhard]] as Le manager ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Powrie, Phil & Rebillard, Éric. ''Pierre Batcheff and stardom in 1920s French cinema''. Edinburgh University Press, 2009 ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0321673}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gentleman of the Ring (1926 film), A}} [[Category:1926 films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Films directed by Gaston Ravel]] [[Category:French silent films]] [[Category:1920s sports films]] [[Category:French sports films]] [[Category:French black-and-white films]] {{1920s-France-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

{{distinguish|Bell Centre}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{coord|49|53|34|N|97|8|37|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Bell MTS Place | nickname = ''The Phone Booth''{{cite news|title=The Phone Booth is rockin'|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/arts-and-life/entertainment/music/The-Phone-Booth-is-rockin--44045232.html|website=Winnipeg Free Press|accessdate=31 May 2017}}{{cite news|last=Kreviazuk|first=Chris|title=Fixing Up The Phone Booth|url=https://www.nhl.com/jets/news/fixing-up-the-phone-booth/c-613230|publisher=Winnipeg Jets|website=NHL.com|date=January 23, 2012|accessdate=February 24, 2018}} | logo_image = [[File:Bell MTS Place Logo.png|125px]] | image = MTS CENTRE b.jpg | image_size = 350px | caption = MTS Centre | address = 300 Portage Avenue | location = [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = April 16, 2003{{cite web|title=Quick Facts|url=http://www.mtscentre.ca/mts-centre-information/quick-facts|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204092317/http://www.mtscentre.ca/mts-centre-information/quick-facts|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 4, 2013|publisher=True North Sports & Entertainment|accessdate=February 5, 2013}} | built = | opened = November 16, 2004 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[True North Sports & Entertainment]] | operator = True North Sports & Entertainment | surface = | construction_cost = [[Canadian dollar|CA]]$133.5 million
{{small|(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|CA|133500000|1998}}}} in {{Inflation-year|CA}} dollars{{inflation-fn|CA}})}} | architect = Sink Combs Dethlefs
Number TEN Architectural Group
Smith Carter | structural engineer = Martin & Martin/Crosier Kilgour[http://www.ckpeng.com/structural_design/projects/ Crosier Kilgour - Projects] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907221806/http://www.ckpeng.com/structural_design/projects/ |date=September 7, 2011 }} | services engineer = M*E/MCW-AGE[http://www.numberten.com/recreation.swf Number TEN Group - Recreation]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | project_manager = [[Hammes Company]] | general_contractor = [[PCL Construction|PCL Constructors Canada Inc.]][http://www.emporis.com/application/?lng=3&nav=building&id=223830 Emporis.com - MTS Centre] | former_names = True North Centre {{small|(planning/construction)}}
MTS Centre {{small|(2004–2017)}} | tenants = [[Winnipeg Jets]] {{small|([[National Hockey League|NHL]]) (2011–present)}}
[[Manitoba Moose]] {{small|([[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (2004–2011, 2015–present)}}
[[Winnipeg Alliance FC]] {{small|([[Canadian Major Indoor Soccer League|CMISL]]) (2007, 2010)}} | seating_capacity = [[Ice hockey]]: 15,321
[[Concert]]s: 16,345 | record_attendance = 17,000 ([[Metallica]] concert - September 13, 2018){{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/metallica-concert-donation-winnipeg-harvest-1.4823490|title=Metallica breaks attendance record, dishes $10K to Winnipeg Harvest|date=September 14, 2018|publisher=CBC.ca}} | dimensions = | website = {{URL|http://www.bellmtsplace.ca/|Venue Website}} }} '''Bell MTS Place''' is an [[indoor arena]] in [[Downtown Winnipeg|downtown]] [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]]. The arena is the home of the [[National Hockey League]]'s [[Winnipeg Jets]] and their [[American Hockey League]] affiliate, the [[Manitoba Moose]].{{cite web | url=http://jets.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=757779&navid=DL | title=True North relocates AHL franchise to Winnipeg | publisher=[[Winnipeg Jets]] | date=March 12, 2015 | accessdate=March 13, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://winnipeg.ctvnews.ca/winnipeggers-and-local-businesses-welcome-ahl-team-1.2277892# | title=Winnipeggers and local businesses welcome AHL team | publisher=[[CTV Winnipeg]] | date=March 12, 2015 | accessdate=March 13, 2015 | author=Roberts, Meghan}}{{cite web | url=http://moosehockey.com/ | title=TRUE NORTH SPORTS & ENTERTAINMENT LIMITED UNVEILS MANITOBA MOOSE AS NAME OF AHL FRANCHISE & ANNOUNCES DETAILS OF TICKET CAMPAIGN | publisher=[[Manitoba Moose]] | work=MooseHockey.com | date=May 4, 2015 | accessdate=May 4, 2015}} The arena stands on the former [[Eaton's#The Winnipeg store|Eaton's]] site and is owned and operated by [[True North Sports & Entertainment]]. The 440,000 square feet (41,000 m2) building was constructed at a cost of $133.5 million [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]. It opened on November 16, 2004, replacing the since-demolished [[Winnipeg Arena]]. It has a capacity of 15,321 for [[ice hockey|hockey]] and 16,345 for concerts. Originally known as the "True North Centre" during its planning and construction stages, it was named the '''MTS Centre''' as part of a [[naming rights]] agreement with [[Manitoba Telecom Services]]. It was renamed Bell MTS Place on May 30, 2017 following [[Bell Canada]]'s acquisition of MTS.{{cite news|title=MTS Centre, Iceplex renamed following Bell takeover of MTS|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/mts-centre-renamed-1.4137892|website=CBC News|agency=Canadian Press|accessdate=30 May 2017}}{{cite news|title=Jets home arena renamed Bell MTS Place|url=https://www.nhl.com/news/winnipeg-home-arena-renamed-bell-mts-place/c-289672910|publisher=National Hockey League|website=NHL.com|date=May 30, 2017|accessdate=February 24, 2018}} ==History== ===Development=== With the bankruptcy of the iconic [[Eaton's]] retailer, the famed store that was originally constructed in Winnipeg was emptied in late 2001. Various alternative uses for the building (including residential condominiums) were suggested, but ultimately the arena was deemed to be the most viable and beneficial to the city's struggling downtown by Winnipeg Mayor [[Glen Murray (politician)|Glen Murray]] and True North.{{cite news |title=The MTS Centre Has Not Revitalized Downtown|first=Nick|last=Ternette|url=http://uniter.ca/view/2607/|work=The Uniter|date=December 3, 2009|accessdate=August 4, 2010}} After a small, but emotional resistance to losing the Western Canadian landmark Eaton's building by some locals and the Save the Eaton's Coalition, which inspired a "group hug" of the "Big Store" by a reported 180 people in 2001, the store was demolished in 2002 to make way for the new entertainment complex. The MTS Centre officially opened on November 16, 2004, replacing the aging [[Winnipeg Arena]], which had been in operation since 1955. In an effort to recognize the store's history, red bricks were incorporated into the design of the arena façade, evoking the memory of the Eaton's store that had once graced Portage Avenue. An original store window and Tyndall stone surround is mounted in the arena concourse to house a collection of Eaton's memorabilia. In addition, two war memorials were incorporated into the building.{{cite web|title=MTS Centre (True North Centre |url=http://www.pcl.com/projects/archived/MTSCentre/index.aspx |publisher=PCL Construction |accessdate=August 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906115206/http://www.pcl.com/projects/archived/MTSCentre/index.aspx |archivedate=September 6, 2008 }} The [[Timothy Eaton statue]] that was once a main feature of the store is also housed in the MTS Centre, near the spot where it stood in the Eaton's building.{{cite web|title=Timothy Eaton statue begins relocation to MTS Centre|url=http://www.mtscentre.ca/press_releases/031029/|publisher=Concertticketcenter.com|date=October 29, 2003|accessdate=July 22, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706185942/http://www.mtscentre.ca/press_releases/031029/|archivedate=July 6, 2011|df=mdy-all}} ===Hockey=== ====American Hockey League==== [[File:Manitobamoosegame.jpg|thumb|left|200px|A [[Manitoba Moose]] game at the MTS Centre]] The AHL's [[Manitoba Moose]] were the arena's first tenant, from its opening in 2004 to 2011. The team relocated to [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]] prior to the [[2011–12 AHL season]] to make way for the arrival of the Winnipeg Jets.{{cite web |title=Thrashers Headed to Winnipeg|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=6610414|work=[[ESPN]]|date=June 1, 2011|accessdate=June 1, 2011}} The Moose returned to the MTS Centre for the [[2015–16 AHL season|2015–16 season]], making the arena the first (together with the [[SAP Center at San Jose]]) to be home to both an NHL team and its AHL affiliate. Only the lower bowl, which has a capacity of 8,812, is used for the majority of Moose home games. The arena hosted the [[AHL All-Star Classic]] on February 1, 2006, in which Team Canada defeated Team PlanetUSA, 9-4. ====National Hockey League==== From 1972 to 1996, the original [[Winnipeg Jets (1972–96)|Winnipeg Jets]] played home games out of the now-demolished Winnipeg Arena. Facing mounting financial troubles, the franchise relocated to [[Arizona]] after the [[1995–96 NHL season]] and became the [[Phoenix Coyotes]]. [[File:Winnipeg Jets first home victory celebration.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Winnipeg Jets celebrate their first regulation win in Winnipeg at the MTS Centre on October 17, 2011.]]The idea of Winnipeg one day returning to the NHL gained momentum after the MTS Centre opened. [[David Thomson, 3rd Baron Thomson of Fleet|David Thomson]] and [[Mark Chipman]] were floated as potential owners of an NHL team, although many questions were raised about the MTS Centre's potential suitability as an NHL venue. The arena's capacity was well below that of the next-smallest NHL arena at that time, the [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]], which sat 16,170 but lacked modern design elements. Chipman stated that the arena's current size was sufficient for an NHL team due to the unique economics of the local market.{{cite news |title=Coyote Question: Is Phoenix an NHL Market?|first=Nick|last=Ternette|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nhl/news?slug=nc-coyotes110310|work=[[Yahoo Sports]]|date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=November 21, 2010}} On May 19, 2011, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' reported that Mark Chipman and True North were finalizing the purchase of the [[Atlanta Thrashers]], with the intent of moving the team to Winnipeg.{{cite news|title=Atlanta Thrashers Moving to Winnipeg|first=Stephen|last=Brunt|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/atlanta-thrashers-moving-to-winnipeg/article2029179/|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=May 19, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520015341/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/atlanta-thrashers-moving-to-winnipeg/article2029179/|archivedate=May 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |title=Sources: Thrashers Deal Not Done|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=6568200|work=[[ESPN]]|date=May 19, 2011|accessdate=May 19, 2011}} Twelve days later, True North chairman [[Mark Chipman]], [[NHL Commissioner]] [[Gary Bettman]], and [[Premier of Manitoba]] [[Greg Selinger]] held a press conference at the MTS Centre to announce the deal, which was formally approved by the NHL Board of Governors three weeks later. As part of the transition to the NHL, the arena went through some minor renovations to bring it in line with the league's standards, including construction of additional press boxes, shuttered lighting, flexible rink glass, and an upgraded ice refrigeration system.{{cite web |title=Daly Says MTS Centre Meets Most League Standards As Is|url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=368402|work=[[The Sports Network|TSN]]|date=June 9, 2011|accessdate=June 9, 2011}} Further improvements were made over the next few years, including concourse improvements, installation of a new high-definition scoreboard, and the replacement of metal rails with plexiglass to eliminate obstructed views around the arena. A total of 278 premium seats were added to the upper level in 2015, slightly increasing the arena's capacity.{{cite news|title=MTS Centre Makeover|url=http://www.winnipegsun.com/2015/09/16/mts-centre-makeover|work=Winnipeg Sun|date=September 16, 2015}} Prior to the return of the Jets, the MTS Centre hosted several NHL preseason games. The first was held on September 17, 2006 between the Edmonton Oilers and the Phoenix Coyotes (the former Winnipeg Jets) in front of a sold-out crowd, which the Oilers won 5–0.{{cite news|title=Former Jets Return to Winnipeg After 10 Years|author=The Canadian Press|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060918.wjets18/BNStory/Sports/Hockey/|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=September 16, 2006|accessdate=May 17, 2009}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The NHL exhibition game became an annual event for the MTS Centre, concluding in September 2010 when the defending [[Stanley Cup Champions]] [[Chicago Blackhawks]], led by captain and Winnipeg-born [[Jonathan Toews]], played the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] in front of a crowd of 14,092.{{cite news |title=Lightning to Host Oilers at MTS Centre|first=Ken|last=Wiebe|url=http://www.winnipegsun.com/sports/hockey/2009/05/05/9359446.html|newspaper=[[Winnipeg Sun]]|date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=May 17, 2009}}' With a capacity of just over 15,300 for NHL games, Bell MTS Place is the smallest arena in the NHL. ====International==== In international hockey, the arena hosted the [[2007 IIHF Women's World Championship]], which was won by the host country. Other international matches hosted at the arena included [[2005 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships|2005 World Junior Championship]] pretournament games, the fifth game of the [[2007 Super Series]] between [[Canada men's national junior ice hockey team|Canada]] and [[Russia men's national junior ice hockey team|Russia]], and the medal round of the [[2011 World U-17 Hockey Challenge]]. ==Events== ===Sports=== *2004 - World Team Challenge (World figure skating team event) *2005 - [[2005 Men's NORCECA Volleyball Championship|Men's NORCECA Volleyball Championship]] *2005 - BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling *2006 - [[2005–06 AHL season|AHL All Star Classic]] *2006 - [[2006 BDO Classic Canadian Open|BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling]] *2007 - [[2007 IIHF Women's World Championship|IIHF Women's World Championship]] *2007 - [[2007 BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling (January)|BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling]] *2007 - Game 5 of the [[2007 Super Series|Canada Russia Junior Super Series]] *2008 - [[2008 Tim Hortons Brier|Tim Hortons Brier]] *2009 - [[2009 Calder Cup playoffs|AHL Calder Cup finals]] *2009 - [[2009 BDO Canadian Open of Curling|BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling]] *2009 - World Deaf Ice Hockey Championship *2009 - Canadian National Ball Hockey Championship *2010 - [[2010 BDO Classic Canadian Open|BDO Classic Canadian Open of Curling]] *2011 - [[World U-17 Hockey Challenge]] *2011 - [[Winnipeg Jets]] inaugural game (October 9) *2013 - [[UFC 161]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ufc.com/news/ufc-161-winnipeg-press-release|title=UFC hits Winnipeg for UFC 161 on June 15|publisher=ufc.com|author=Staff |date=2013-03-05|accessdate=2013-03-05}} *2013 - [[2013 Canadian Olympic Curling Trials|Canadian Olympic Curling Trials]] *2015 - [[2015 Stanley Cup playoffs|Winnipeg Jets first playoff game]] (April 20) ===Entertainment=== {{main|List of entertainment events at Bell MTS Place}} ==Manitoba Hockey Hall of Fame and Museum== {{main|Manitoba Hockey Hall of Fame}} ==See also== *[[List of indoor arenas in Canada]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Bell MTS Place}} *{{Official website|http://www.bellmtsplace.ca/}} {{s-start}} {{Succession box | before = [[Winnipeg Arena]] | title = Home of the [[Manitoba Moose]] | years = 2004–2011 | after = [[Mile One Centre]]
(as [[St. John's IceCaps]])}} {{Succession box | before = [[Mile One Centre]]
(as [[St. John's IceCaps]]) | title = Home of the [[Manitoba Moose]] | years = 2015–present | after = present}} {{Succession box | before = [[Philips Arena]]
(as [[Atlanta Thrashers]]) | title = Home of the [[Winnipeg Jets]] | years = 2011–present | after = present}} {{s-end}} {{Winnipeg Jets}} {{Manitoba Moose}} {{TrueNorthSportsEntertainment}} {{Bell Canada}} {{NHL Arenas}} {{AHL Arenas}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Canada]] [[Category:Bell Canada]] [[Category:Curling venues in Canada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Manitoba]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Manitoba Moose]] [[Category:National Hockey League venues]] [[Category:Music venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Music venues in Winnipeg]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Sports venues in Winnipeg]] [[Category:True North Sports & Entertainment]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Canada]] [[Category:Winnipeg Jets]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Bike Calgary | logo = | type = [[Nonprofit]] | foundation = 2008
[[Calgary]], [[Alberta]] | location = CommunityWise Resource Centre, [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]] | area_served = Calgary | industry = [[Cycling]] | num_employees= 50 (volunteers) | homepage = [http://www.bikecalgary.org Bike Calgary] }} '''Bike Calgary''' is a member-based [[non-profit]] organization advocating for and promoting [[transportation cycling]] with over 1,300 members, based in [[Calgary|Calgary, Alberta]], [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://bikecalgary.org/about |title=About |publisher=Bike Calgary |date= |accessdate=2013-11-15}} == History == Bike Calgary was formed as an informal group of cyclists in 2005 and at first existed mainly as a website that served to disseminate information on cycling in Calgary, and incorporated as a non-profic society in 2008. In 2011, under the guidance of [[CivicCamp]], Bike Calgary began to take on a broader advocacy role.Godin, Dan. [http://fes.yorku.ca/files/outstanding_papers/MESMajorPaperFinalSept2012.pdf "Cycling Advocacy, DIY Urbanism and the Transformation of Automobility"], Master's thesis, [[York University]], 31 July 2012. Retrieved 14 November 2013.Andre, Todd. [http://www.avenuecalgary.com/articles/civiccamp-engages-calgarians-to-create-a-more-liveable-city "CivicCamp Engages Calgarians to Create a More Liveable City"], ''Avenue Calgary'', 27 September 2012. Retrieved 14 November 2013. == Initiatives == Bike Calgary lobbied [[Calgary Transit]] to allow [[folding bicycles]] on buses and trains at all times, which it now does.Nolais, Jeremy. [http://metronews.ca/news/calgary/21031/folding-bikes-to-be-allowed-on-transit/ "Folding bikes to be allowed on transit"], ''[[Metro International|Metro]] Calgary'', 3 June 2011. Retrieved 14 November 2013. It has also been involved in the implementation of Calgary's Cycling Strategy.Anderson, Drew. [http://www.ffwdweekly.com/article/life-style/urban-living/calgarys-slow-but-steady-cycling-plan-10850/ "Calgary's slow but steady cycling plan"], ''[[Fast Forward Weekly]]'', 6 June 2013. Retrieved 14 November 2013. In 2014, it led a successful campaign to implement a pilot network of [[Segregated cycle facilities|protected bike lanes]] in [[Downtown Calgary]] and the [[Beltline, Calgary|Beltline]].Andersen, Michael. [http://www.peopleforbikes.org/blog/entry/three-lessons-from-calgarys-sudden-leap-to-become-a-protected-lane-leader "Three lessons from Calgary’s sudden leap to become a bike-lane leader"], ''[[People for Bikes]] blog'', 29 April 2013. Retrieved 3 May 2014. == Cycling courses == Bike Calgary has developed and offers a one-day Urban Cycling Skills course for a nominal fee. It is based on the [[CAN-BIKE]] curriculum.{{cite web|url=http://bikecalgary.org/skills |title=Urban Cycling Skills |publisher=Bike Calgary |date= |accessdate=2013-11-15}}Babin, Tom. [http://blogs.calgaryherald.com/2011/08/23/urban-skills-course-gives-confidence-to-cyclists-riding-downtown/ "Urban skills course gives confidence to cyclists riding downtown"], ''[[Calgary Herald]] Pedal Blog'', 23 August 2011. Retrieved on 14 November 2013. == See also == * [[Transportation in Calgary]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bikecalgary.org}} [[Category:Organizations based in Calgary]] [[Category:Cycling organizations in Canada]] {{Canada-sport-stub}} {{Canada-transport-stub}}

revision.comment: Updated page link for linked page's name change.
revision.text:
[[File:Bowlmor logo.png|thumb|right|Bowlmor Lanes logo]] '''Bowlmor Lanes''' is the upscale brand of [[ten-pin bowling]] and entertainment centers operated by [[Bowlero Corporation]]. There are currently 18 Bowlmor Lanes centers, nine of which are former [[300 Bowling and Entertainment Centers|AMF 300]] centers and three are former [[AMF Bowling Center|AMF Bowling Centers]].
Bowlmor Lanes centers aim to provide "high-end" bowling in a modern lounge setting which includes audiovisual technology, such as plasma screens for automatic scoring and movie screens above the lanes, plus glow lighting, and glow-in-the-dark lanes. Bowlmor Lanes centers also have DJ booths, sports bars and video arcades, miniature golf, bocce, table shuffleboard, ping pong tables, air hockey, billiards, and boardwalk games, private party facilities with catering services, and full service restaurants.<ref name="reorg">{{cite web|title=Disclosure Statement for the Second Modified Joint Plan of Reorganization of AMF Bowling Worldwide, Inc., and its Debtor Affiliates Pursuant to Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (Document 818), Case No. 12-36495, United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, Richmond Division|url=http://www.kccllc.net/documents/1236495/1236495130523000000000010.pdf|accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> Bowlero claims its Bowlmor Lanes brand has a 35-50% return on equity.<ref name="interview">{{cite web|title=Interview with Bowlmor Lanes Founder and CEO Tom Shannon|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ekEgTqQkMQ#t=166|newspaper=Bloomberg Enterprise (TV)|date=October 27, 2011 }}</ref>
==Early history== [[File:Bowlmor Lanes Times Square (Manhattan, New York) 001 crop.jpg|thumb|right|Bowlmor Lanes Times Square]]
In 1938 Nick Gianos opened the original Bowlmor Lanes in [[New York City]]'s [[Union Square, Manhattan|Union Square]]. The opening came right at the start of the Golden Age of bowling, the 1940s through the 1960s, when the invention of the automatic [[pinsetter]] propelled bowling's popularity to its highest. Bowlmor Lanes was at the forefront of the bowling revolution, hosting the prestigious Landgraf Tournament in 1942 and one of the first televised bowling tournaments, the East vs. West, broadcast on New York City radio station [[WOR (AM)|WOR]] in 1954. In 1958, Vice President [[Richard Nixon]] bowled at the center.<ref name="NY Times">{{cite web|title=Nixon Bowled Here, but Owner Looks to the Future|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/nyregion/nixon-bowled-here-but-owner-looks-to-the-future.html|newspaper= The New York Times|date=April 5, 1997}}</ref> Through the 70's and 80's Bowlmor Lanes was home to the top bowlers in the sport.<ref name="70's and 80's ">[http://www.actionbowlers.com/great_action_houses.htm Actionbowlers.com]</ref>
Nick Gianos's son John took over the business in 1981, and by 1997 he was feeling the pressure of rising rent and the need to modernize.<ref name="NY Times"/>
That year, 1992 [[Darden School of Business]] graduate Tom Shannon attended a birthday party at the now dilapidated bowling center. Shannon saw the potential in the property and purchased it for $1.4 million "to inject the tired business with hip design, upscale cuisine, and a full bar, and then market Bowlmor as a party venue."<ref name="Crains">{{cite web|title=Top Entrepreneurs 2008|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/gallery/20080501/FEATURES/501009997/5|newspaper=Crain’s New York Business|accessdate=March 9, 2014}}</ref>
Shannon then borrowed $2 million from friends, family, and Bowlmor's sellers to transform the center. Changes included installation of video screens, glow in the dark lanes and balls, and lane-side food and drink service. Shannon eliminated [[bowling league]]s, "to ease out those who did not cotton to the fancy trappings or higher prices," in favor of promotions and events aimed at attracting new fans to the sport. By 1999, Bowlmor Lanes Union Square was the highest-grossing bowling center in the United States.<ref name="reorg"/><ref name="Crains"/> The center was closed in July 2014 when it lost its lease.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bowlmor Lanes, city's oldest bowling alley, closes after 76-year run in Union Square|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/bowlmor-lanes-closes-article-1.1857949#ixzz36sdAHWlq|newspaper=New York Daily News|date=July 7, 2014}}</ref>
==More locations== With the success of the Union Square location, Shannon’s company, Strike Holdings LLC, went on to replicate the Bowlmor Lanes concept in other markets. In 2001, Strike [[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] opened in suburban [[Washington, D.C.]] A year later, Strike [[Long Island]] was opened in an underground space housing 35 lanes of bowling, a full-service restaurant, and four bars. In November 2004, the 34 lane Strike [[Miami]] opened in the Dolphin Mall in the Doral section of the city, featuring a sports themed restaurant. Strike [[Cupertino]] ([[Silicon Valley]]), California opened at [[Vallco Shopping Mall]] in the summer of 2007 and Strike [[Orange County, California|Orange County]], CA opened in the summer of 2008. The properties were rebranded as Bowlmor Lanes soon after.<ref name="reorg"/>
In the fall of 2010, Strike Holdings opened its largest location in the former [[New York Times]] newsroom in New York City's [[Times Square]]. The {{convert|90000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Bowlmor Lanes facility features seven bowling lounges designed with New York themes, from [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Manhattan Chinatown]] (featuring a gong that is hit upon bowling a strike) to [[Art Deco]] and [[Central Park, Manhattan|Central Park]] (including items purchased from the [[Tavern on the Green]] auction) to [[Prohibition]], plus a full stage with dance floor, a sports bar with stadium-style seating, boardwalk games, and a miniature golf course.<ref name="reorg"/><ref name="NY Post">{{cite news |title= Bowlmor 2.0 rolling into Times Square |newspaper=[[New York Post]] |url= http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/bowlmore_rolling_to_times_square_ZmMVEQsMyLskr4tyd1jmyN |date= February 22, 2010}}</ref>
==Operations== Bowlmor's revenues rose from approximately $1.9 million from its single facility in the year ending December 31, 1997 (close to double the revenues for the same facility in the prior year under prior management) to approximately $37.1 million for all locations in the year ending December 31, 2012. Bowlmor locations have earned several hundred thousand dollars per lane per year making it one of the highest grossing bowling facility operators in North America.<ref name="reorg"/>
In 2013 the much larger [[AMF Bowling|AMF Bowling Worldwide]] was reorganized and combined with Strike Holdings LLC to form Bowlmor AMF (now known as [[Bowlero Corporation]]), with Tom Shannon as its Chairman, Chief Executive Officer, and President.<ref name="reorg"/>
==Accolades== Shannon was named Bowling Proprietor of the Year in 2001<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Profile: Thomas F. Shannon|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=5477918&privcapId=4100559&previousCapId=4100559&previousTitle=Bowlmor+Holdings+LLC|newspaper=Bloomberg Businessweek|accessdate=March 9, 2014}}</ref> and again in 2014<ref>{{cite news|title=Centers of Attention: Bowlmor AMF's Tom Shannon knows how to draw a crowd|newspaper=[[Bowlers Journal|Bowlers Journal International]]|date=June 2014}}</ref> by [[Bowlers Journal|Bowlers Journal International Magazine]] and a Top Entrepreneur of 2008 by [[Crain's New York Business]].<ref name="Crains"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Bowlmor Lanes}} *http://www.bowlmor.com

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Charlotte Lady Eagles | image = Charlotte Lady Eagles logo.svg | image_size = 200px | fullname = Charlotte Lady Eagles | nickname = Lady Eagles | founded = 2000 | stadium = [[Queens University of Charlotte Royals|Dickson Field, Queens University]]
[[Charlotte, North Carolina]] | capacity = 2,500 | chairman = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Pat Stewart]] | manager = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Sam Hope (soccer)|Sam Hope]] | league = {{nowrap|[[Women's Premier Soccer League]]}} | season = | position = | pattern_la1=_whiteborder | pattern_b1=_ctwhales_away | pattern_ra1=_whiteborder | leftarm1=F87217 | body1=F87217 | rightarm1=F87217 | shorts1=FFFFFF | socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2=_whiteborder | pattern_b2=_thinwhitesides | pattern_ra2=_whiteborder | leftarm2=306EFF | body2=306EFF | rightarm2=306EFF | shorts2=000000 | socks2=306EFF | }} '''Charlotte Lady Eagles''' is an American women's [[soccer]] team, founded in 2000. Between 2002 and 2015 the Lady Eagles were a member of the [[United Soccer Leagues]] [[USL W-League]], the second tier of women's soccer in the United States and Canada, and a member of the W-2 League between 2000 and 2002. The team plays its home games at [[Queens University of Charlotte Royals|Dickson Field, Queens University]] in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. The club's colors are orange, sky blue and white. The Lady Eagles are a division of [[Missionary Athletes International]] (MAI), an organization committed to sharing the message of [[Christianity]] through [[sports ministry]]. They are a sister organization of the MAI men's [[USL League Two]] franchises the [[Charlotte Eagles]] and the [[Southern California Seahorses]]. While the W-League folded in 2015, MAI announced plans to continue training women and girls as players and coaches.http://charlotteeagles.com/home/871822.html After two years playing an independent schedule, the Lady Eagles joined the [[Women's Premier Soccer League]] for the 2019 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.wpslsoccer.com/news_article/show/969874|title=Charlotte Lady Eagles join WPSL as 2019 expansion club|publisher=WPSL Communications|date=November 19, 2018}} ==Players== ===Current roster 2015=== {{Fs start}} {{Fs player|no=1|nat=USA|name=[[Alex Kubrick]]|pos=GK|}} {{Fs {{Infobox tennis biography | name = Clément Morel | image = | fullname = Clément Morel | country_represented = {{FRA}}
{{MON}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|7|16|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Oullins]], [[Lyon]], France | death_date = | death_place = | plays = Right-handed | careerprizemoney = $43,924 | singlesrecord = 0–1 | singlestitles = 0 | highestsinglesranking = No. 387 (15/10/2007) | currentsinglesranking = | AustralianOpenjuniorresult = '''W''' ([[2002 Australian Open|2002]]) | doublesrecord = 0–0 | doublestitles = 0 | highestdoublesranking = No. 509 (1/10/2007) | currentdoublesranking = }} '''Clément Morel''' (born 16 July 1984) is a former professional [[tennis]] player from France. ==Career== Morel was the junior champion at the [[2002 Australian Open]]. He defeated countryman [[Jo-Wilfried Tsonga]] in the semi-finals, then won the title with a win over [[Todd Reid]] in the final.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/tennis/australian_open/1784882.stm|title=Johansson surprises himself|last=Banks|first=Colin|date=27 January 2002|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} In the juniors event at the [[2002 Wimbledon Championships]], Morel lost in the second round to [[Ryan Henry]], with a final set scoreline of 24-26, which was a tournament record.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/funny_old_game/2095702.stm|title=Long-playing record finally smashed|date=4 July 2002|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=8 December 2015}} He took part in qualifying for the [[2004 French Open]] and also appeared in an [[ATP Challenger Tour|ATP Challenger]] tournament in [[Grenoble Challenger|Grenoble]] that year, but otherwise played on the [[ITF Men's Circuit|Futures circuit]]. His two Futures titles came in South Africa in 2006 and the other a 2008 tournament in Belgium. In 2008 he switched nationalities and began representing the [[Monaco Davis Cup team]]. He played two matches, the first was a win over Algerian [[Slimane Saoudi]] in 2008 and the other a loss to Finland's [[Henri Laaksonen]] the following year.{{cite web|url=http://www.daviscup.com/en/draws-results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=100010197|title=Davis Cup - Tie - Details - Monaco v Algeria|publisher=daviscup.com|accessdate=8 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.daviscup.com/en/draws-results/tie/details.aspx?tieId=100012309|title=Davis Cup - Tie - Details - Finland v Monaco|publisher=daviscup.com|accessdate=8 December 2015}} ==Junior Grand Slam finals== ===Singles: 1 (1–0)=== {|class="sortable wikitable" style=font-size:97% !width=80|Outcome !width=10|No. !width=50|Year !width=200|Tournament !width=75|Surface !width=200|Opponent !width=140|Score |- |bgcolor=98FB98|Winner |1. |2002 |[[2002 Australian Open|Melbourne]], [[Australia]] |Hard |{{flagicon|AUS}} [[Todd Reid]] |6–4, 6–4 |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{ATP|MB29}} * {{Davis Cup player|800223154}} * {{ITF profile|100002665}} {{Australian Open boys' singles champions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Morel, Clement}} [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French male tennis players]] [[Category:Monegasque male tennis players]] [[Category:Australian Open (tennis) junior champions]] {{France-tennis-bio-stub}} {{Monaco-tennis-bio-stub}}

[[Peoria, Illinois|Peoria, IL]] 61605 | coordinates = {{coord|40|41|15|N|89|35|51|W|type:landmark_region:US-IL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = {{start date|2001|8|16}} | built = | opened = {{start date|2002|5|24}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Peoria Chiefs|Peoria Chiefs Community Baseball LLC]] | operator = Peoria Chiefs Community Baseball LLC | surface = [[Sod]] (1–1¼ inches) | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]23 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|23000000|2002}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[HNTB]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = Clark Engineers MW Inc.{{cite web |title=O'Brien Field|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2002/05/20020527/Facilities/Obrien-Field.aspx|work=SportsBusiness Journal|date=May 27, 2002|accessdate=September 17, 2011}} | general_contractor = River City Construction LLC | project_manager = | main_contractors = Prairie Construction Systems Inc. | former_names = '''O'Brien Field''' (2002–2008)
'''Chiefs Stadium''' (2009–2013) | tenants = [[Peoria Chiefs]] ([[Midwest League|MWL]]) (2002–present)
[[Bradley Braves baseball|Bradley Braves]] ([[NCAA]]) (2002–present) | capacity = 8,500 | dimensions = Left Field: 310 ft (94.49 m)
Left Center: 375 ft (114.3 m)
Center Field: 400 ft (121.92 m)
Right Center: 375 ft (114.3 m)
Right Field: 310 ft (94.49 m) }} '''Dozer Park''', originally '''O'Brien Field''' and formerly '''Chiefs Stadium''', is a [[baseball]] field located in downtown [[Peoria, Illinois]].{{cite news |title=Caterpillar Names Baseball Stadium 'Dozer Park'|first=Kevin|last=Cape|url=http://www.pjstar.com/news/x1865974969/Dozer-Park-is-new-name-for-Peoria-baseball-stadium|newspaper=[[Journal Star (Peoria)]]|date=May 10, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}} It is the home of the [[Peoria Chiefs]], the Class A affiliate of the [[St. Louis Cardinals]]; the Chiefs previously played at [[Meinen Field]]. The [[college baseball]] team of [[Bradley University]] also uses the field. It opened on May 24, 2002.{{cite web |title=Chiefs Stadium Renamed Dozer Park|url=http://www.milb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20130509&content_id=47104060&fext=.jsp&vkey=news_t443&sid=t44|publisher=Peoria Chiefs|date=May 10, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}} ==History== Official groundbreaking ceremonies for the $23 million [[multi-purpose stadium]] took place on August 16, 2001.{{cite news |title=South Bend Takes Pair of Games from Chiefs|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BL&p_theme=bl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F01FD1624182550&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=[[The Pantagraph]]|location=Bloomington–Normal|date=August 11, 2001|accessdate=August 11, 2013}} The stadium opened on May 24, 2002 as O'Brien Field, with a game between the Chiefs and the [[Kane County Cougars]].{{cite web |title=Stadium History|url=http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?ymd=20081202&content_id=41469004&sid=t443&vkey=team1|publisher=Peoria Chiefs|date=December 2, 2008|accessdate=August 11, 2013}} O'Brien Auto Team held the original [[naming rights]] to the facility. In 2011, the stadium hosted to the [[Illinois High School Association|IHSA]] Class 1A and 2A baseball state finals. This was the first year the games were played at the facility.{{cite web |title=Baseball State Finals: 1A/2A Tournament Moves To Peoria, 3A/4A Extended In Joliet |url=http://www.ihsa.org/announce/2010-11/2010-10-12.htm |publisher=Illinois High School Association |accessdate=June 8, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zIGtHzjE?url=http://www.ihsa.org/announce/2010-11/2010-10-12.htm |archivedate=June 8, 2011 |date=October 12, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In April 2013, the Chiefs, including the stadium, received $7.35 million in financing and debt forgiveness. The plan included forgiveness of $1.2 million in debt to the City of Peoria; including $2 million in funding from [[Caterpillar Inc.]] for [[naming rights]] over 10 years; and $2.7 million in new investment of cash and equity by the Chiefs' ownership group of about 50.{{cite news |title=Peoria City Council Approves Financial Restructuring for Chiefs|first=Nick|last=Vlahos|url=http://www.pjstar.com/news/x1213308616/City-Council-approves-financial-bailout-for-Chiefs|newspaper=[[Journal Star (Peoria)]]|date=April 30, 2013|accessdate=May 10, 2013}} On May 10, 2013, Caterpillar and the Chiefs announced that the stadium would be renamed "Dozer Park", a reference to Caterpillar [[bulldozer]]s. ==The field== Dozer Park's [[sod]] has an {{convert|8|in|mm|adj=on}} deep root zone of 90% sand and 10% Dakota peat for nutrition. The high concentration of sand naturally relieves soil compaction. Beneath the sand and peat mix are {{convert|6|in|mm}} of [[gravel]]. Running through the gravel are drainage tiles that run from [[home plate]] to [[Baseball field#outfield|center field]]. A huge sump pump beyond center field then drains into the city sewer system. The makeup of the pitcher's mound and batter's boxes are almost 100% clay because it packs better and is wear resistant. The rest of the infield skin area is around 40% clay, 30% silt and 20% sand. The field will hold up to {{convert|5|in|mm}} of rain an hour. The field is mowed every day during homestands, trimmed to {{convert|1|-|1+1/4|in|mm}} high. It takes 1.25 hours to cut the outfield grass 2 directions with a {{convert|100|in|m|sing=on}} cut mower. A walk-behind mower is used for the [[infield]]. The price tag for the field itself was around $450,000.{{cite news |title=Guide to O'Brien Field|first=Dave|last=Reynolds|url=http://www.pjstar.com/services/special/2002obrienfield/stories/g93817a.html|newspaper=[[Journal Star (Peoria)]]|accessdate=August 11, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020603222155/http://www.pjstar.com/services/special/2002obrienfield/stories/g93817a.html|archivedate=June 3, 2002}} ==Luxury suites== Dozer Park accommodates 20 luxury suites. Examples include: * Peoria attorney Jay Janssen’s suite — "A large, ornate [[Oriental rug]] covers most of the green-carpeted suite, which includes six [[candelabra]] wall sconces, a [[chandelier]] in the center, cherry wood [[cabinetry]] and chair rail, decorative border print, a green [[marble]]-topped [[Table (furniture)|table]], a rose-colored [[granite]] [[pedestal]] bar overlooking the field and burgundy [[leather]] [[Chair|stools]] and [[chairs]]. In the [[kitchenette]], a full-sized [[refrigerator]] is accompanied by a full-size [[oven]] and a [[sink]] with a chrome-plated [[faucet]]."{{cite news |title=Big-League Style Ballpark a Hit in Peoria|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_multi=JS&p_product=JS&p_theme=gatehouse&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&s_dispstring=jay%20janssen%20suite%20AND%20date(all)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(jay%20janssen%20suite)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no#ixzz2bikm6l7h|newspaper=[[Journal Star (Peoria)]]|date=October 19, 2002|accessdate=August 11, 2013}} * [[Caterpillar, Inc.]] owns a double suite that is primarily used to entertain the customers and [[VIP]] guests the company hosts in the community. ==Food== Other than the five fixed [[Concession stand|concession]] stands there are mobile carts around the park. The Chiefs' concessionaire is Professional Sports Catering.{{cite web |title=Who We're Working With|url=http://www.prosportscatering.com/minor_league_baseball.html|publisher=Professional Sports Catering|accessdate=August 11, 2013}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t443&ymd=20081120&content_id=481993&vkey=team1 Ballpark - Peoria Chiefs Dozer Park] * [http://www.bradleybraves.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=130293 Dozer Park - Bradley University Athletics] {{Bradley University}} {{Midwest League Ballparks}} {{Missouri Valley Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Illinois NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:Bradley Braves baseball]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Peoria, Illinois]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Peoria, Illinois]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Peoria, Illinois]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Illinois]]

revision.comment: Gruesome Gary moved page [[Estadio Alsalsias]] to [[Estadio Alsacias]]: corr sp

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox venue | name = Estádio Urbano Caldeira | nickname = Vila Belmiro | image = [[File:Estádio_Urbano_Caldeira-2003-01-18.jpg|250px]] | caption = Estádio Urbano Caldeira | fullname = | location = Rua Princesa Isabel,
Vila Belmiro neighborhood,
[[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]], Brazil | coordinates = {{coord|23|57|4|S|46|20|20|W|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1916 | opened = October 12, 1916 | renovated = March 27, 1997 | expanded = March 27, 1997 | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 31662}} (Santos vs [[Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras|Palmeiras]], 15 February 1976){{citeweb|url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/vila-belmiro/ |title=Vila Belmiro |publisher=SantosFC.com.br |language=Portuguese |date=27 July 2016}} | owner = Santos FC | operator = Santos FC | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Yes | architect = | tenants = [[Santos FC|Santos]] ([[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Série A]]) (1916–present) | seating_capacity = 16,068{{cite web|url=http://cdn.cbf.com.br/content/201601/20160122182359_0.pdf |title=CNEF - Cadastro Nacional de Estádios de Futebol|date=January 18, 2016 |accessdate=June 3, 2016 |language=Portuguese}} | dimensions = 105 × 80 [[metre|m]] (114.8 × 87.5 [[yard|yd]]) }} '''Estádio Urbano Caldeira''', also known as '''Estádio Vila Belmiro''', is an [[association football]] [[stadium]] located in the Vila Belmiro neighborhood of [[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]], [[Brazil]], and the home of [[Santos Futebol Clube]].{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/clube/default.asp?c=Sedes&st=Vila%20Belmiro |title=Estádio Urbano Caldeira |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020200357/http://www.santosfc.com.br/clube/default.asp?c=Sedes&st=Vila%20Belmiro |archive-date=October 20, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The ground was inaugurated on October 12, 1916 when Santos beat [[Clube Atlético Ypiranga]] 2–1, with [[Adolfo Millon Jr.]] scoring the first goal of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.portogente.com.br/texto.php?cod=2386 |title=A inauguração do nosso estádio |publisher=Porto Gente |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910034814/http://www.portogente.com.br/texto.php?cod=2386 |archivedate=September 10, 2011 |df= }} It was named in honor of [[Urbano Caldeira]], former player, manager and chairman of Santos, in 1933.{{cite web|url=http://www.tiosam.org/enciclopedia/index.asp?q=Est%C3%A1dio_Urbano_Caldeira |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415230134/http://www.tiosam.org/enciclopedia/index.asp?q=Est%C3%A1dio_Urbano_Caldeira |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 15, 2013 |title=Estádio Urbano Caldeira |publisher=Tio Sam |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |df= }} The ground, given the nickname ''Vila Belmiro'' due to its location within the Vila Belmiro neighborhood, has been Santos' permanent residence since 1916.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/south_america/brazil/sao_paulo/santos_caldeira.shtml |title=Estádio Urbano Caldeira (Vila Belmiro) |publisher=World Stadiums |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804063002/http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/south_america/brazil/sao_paulo/santos_caldeira.shtml |archivedate=August 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} However, the club sometimes uses the [[Estádio do Pacaembu|Pacaembu Stadium]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pacaembu.com.br/ |title=Pacaembu |publisher=Pacaembu |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese}} located in the city of [[São Paulo]] for important matches due to the low capacity of Vila Belmiro. The ground underwent several expansions and renovations in the 1990s and 2000s (decade), most notably the renewal of the irrigation and drainage systems, flood-lighting and the replacement of the field. The stadium's current highest attendance was recorded in 1964, when 32,989 spectators watched the [[Campeonato Paulista]] match between Santos and [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]].{{cite web|url=http://classicoeclassico.sites.uol.com.br/sp/corxsan_estadio.htm |title=Vila Belmiro |publisher=Clássico é Clássico |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese}} ==Location== The Estádio Urbano Caldeira is located on the Princesa Isabel street, in the neighborhood of Vila Belmiro, occupying the block bounded by the streets of Tiradentes, Don Pedro I, and José de Alencar.{{cite web|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?ll=-23.951111,-46.338889&spn=0.01,0.01&t=m&q=-23.951111,-46.338889 |title=Google Maps: Vila Belmiro |publisher=[[Google Maps]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} The venue is 600 feet (182.88 meters) in between the avenues of Senator Pinheiro Machado and Dr. Bernadino de Campos.{{cite web|url=http://maps.yahoo.com/broadband/#mvt=m&lat=-23.951111&lon=-46.338889&mag=6&zoom=17&q1=-23.951111%2C-46.338889 |title=Yahoo! Maps: Vila Belmiro |publisher=[[Yahoo! Maps]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} ==History== {{Quote box |quote = ...Santos currently can afford to proudly say that it maintains a sports center that rivals any one in the state (of São Paulo)... |source =—Mário Bezerra da Silva, a club member, during Santos' 1981st game in 1981. |align = right |quoted = 1 |width = 33% }} Soon after its foundation, Santos held their training in a field located in the neighborhood of Macuco.{{cite web|url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/historia/default.asp?c=Hist%F3ria&st=A%20Trajet%F3ria |title=A Trajetória |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |df=mdy }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}} As the field did not meet the minimum size standards to host official matches, Santos played on the "Igreja Coração de Maria" pitch in Ana Costa Avenue.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70617 |title=Vila Belmiro- 92 anos de fundação |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121231170905/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70617 |archivedate=December 31, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} The field, however, was also used by other clubs in town. In 1915, the situation reached its breaking point, when Santos had constant conflicts with other city clubs on when the field could be used, forcing the club to reject several requests for international friendlies.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=14615#.Tlg2hV1m2-A |title=Estádio Urbano Caldeira completa 89 anos nesta quarta-feira |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072259/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=14615#.Tlg2hV1m2-A |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} To solve the problem, the leaders began searching for land in the city, with a commission formed by Luiz Suplicy Júnior, Harold Cross, Sebastião Arantes Nogueira and Francisco Viriato Corrêa da Costa. On May 31, 1916, a general assembly approved the purchase of an area of 16,500 square meters, in the neighborhood of Vila Belmiro, approved by [[List of Santos FC presidents|club president]] Agnello Cícero de Oliveira and vice-president Dr. Álvaro Ribeiro. The land acquired belonged to ''Companhia de Habitações Econômicas'', and the field was bought from them at a price of [[Brazilian real (old)|Rs$]]66,660,000. The board members obtained a 10-year loan which was liquified in 1923 after paying Rs$35,000,000 in interest fees. [[File:Inauguracao.png|thumb|right|225px|Estádio Urbano Caldeira during its inauguration]] The club, however, did not obtain a nearby area belonging to ''Beneficência Portuguesa'', since the club's finances did not favor this. It would not be acquired until 1989. The original date for the inauguration of the field was August 20; it was postponed until further notice due to the death of Dr. Álvaro Ribeiro. On October 12 of that year, the inauguration of the ''Vila Belmiro'' sports park was celebrated with several ceremonies among the members, including a march by musical corporation ''Humanitária'', to see off playing on Macuco field. The first game was held 10 days later at 13:30 ([[UTC-3]]),{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70649 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072307/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70649 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |title=O primeiro jogo do nosso estádio |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese }} against [[Clube Atlético Ypiranga|Ypiranga]] for the [[1916 Campeonato Paulista]], the competition's 491st match, which Santos won 2–1. Ticket prices were set at Rs$2 for bleacher and Rs$1 for the general public. [[Adolfo Millon Jr.]] scored the first ever goal on that stadium with Jarbas scoring the second, while Bororó scored for the visiting team. Santos was formed by: Odorico; Américo and Arantes; Pereira, Oscar and Junqueira; Millon, Marba, Tedesco, Jarbas and Arnaldo. Ypiranga was represented by Dionísio; Dario and Ferreira; Loschiavo, Jacintho and Peres II; Ary, Hugo, Bororó, Peres I and Formiga. Demosthenes de Silos was the referee for the match. ===Early years=== [[File:Vila Belmiro 1931.png|thumb|right|Santos' first match during the night took place on March 21, 1931]] The first major renovation occurred in 1931.{{cite web |url=http://canelada.com.br/caneladas-historicas/historia-dos-estadios-brasileiros-vila-belmiro/ |title=História dos Estádios Brasileiros – Vila Belmiro |publisher=Tiago Buckowsky Xavier |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331074702/http://canelada.com.br/caneladas-historicas/historia-dos-estadios-brasileiros-vila-belmiro/ |archivedate=March 31, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} On March 21, of that year, the stadium renovated its stands and an illumination system was installed. Twenty hours later, the club's first late match was played against a combined team from the city of Santos, with the club losing to its city counterpart 0–1. Manoel Cruz, a midfielder from [[Associação Atlética Portuguesa Santista|Portuguesa Santista]], scored the only goal of the match. After Urbano Caldeira died on March 12, 1933, Ricardo Pinto de Oliveira, one of the club board members at that time, wanted to pay homage to Caldeira by naming the stadium after him. After a meeting which included all club members, the naming of the stadium was given a positive vote.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=21959#.Tlg05l1m2-A |title=Há 77 anos, Vila ganhava o nome de Estádio Urbano Caldeira |publisher=Santos Futebol Clube |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072245/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=21959#.Tlg05l1m2-A |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} Twenty-two years later, the first concrete stand was built where the current electrical score–keeping screen is located at. Called ''A Vila Mais Famosa do Mundo'' (The World's Most Famous Village), the Estádio Urbano Caldeira also came to be called after the era of ''[[Os Santásticos]]'' (1956–1973) the "Alçapão da Vila (The Village Trap) because opposing team often left the ground defeated. Due to the proximity of the stands with the field where the matches unfolds, the pressure that the fans have on opposing teams was said to be incredible. After the golden age, the Vila Belmiro became synonymous with ''[[The Beautiful Game|Joga Bonito]]''.{{cite book |last=Cunha |first=Odir |title=Time dos Sonhos |trans-title=Dream Teams |year=2003 |ISBN=85-7594-020-1 |language=Portuguese }} [[File:Vila1950.png|thumb|right|225px|The first concrete stand was built in 1955.]] In that stadium of modest dimensions, stars of past and present such Pelé, Coutinho, Pepe, Giovanni, Pitta, Robinho, Diego, Neymar and Paulo Henrique Ganso became figures for the national team. For many years Vila Belmiro was the place where [[Pelé]] demonstrated his skills. On November 21, 1964, at Vila Belmiro, Pelé scored eight goals against [[Botafogo Futebol Clube (SP)|Botafogo (SP)]], when Santos beat the opposing squad 11–0. On October 2, 1974, Pelé played his farewell game at the stadium. In that match, Santos beat [[Associação Atlética Ponte Preta|Ponte Preta]] 2–0. The stadium's attendance record currently stands at 32,989, set on September 20, 1964 when Santos and [[Sport Club Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]] drew 0–0.{{cite web|url=http://www.meutimao.com.br/estadios-em-que-o-corinthians-jogou/vila_belmiro/ |title=Urbano Caldeira |publisher=Meu Timão |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese}} However, the record was overshadowed by a tragic event, as part of the stadium bleachers collapsed, resulting in injury to 181 spectators. The match was abandoned and rescheduled 10 days later, in the [[Estádio do Pacaembu|Pacaembu]]. {{clear}} ===Development=== During the [[1996 Campeonato Paulista]], the stadium was closed because the field was in a poor condition. During this time Santos FC played in many stadiums, including the [[Estádio Bruno José Daniel]] in [[Santo André]] and the [[Estádio do Pacaembu|Pacaembu Stadium]] in [[São Paulo]]. After that, the stadium was modified to adopt a system of drainage and irrigation systems controlled by computer. On July 20, 1997, Santos inaugurated the new stadium bleachers, located behind the goal net where, today, the visiting fans are located at.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=22538#.Tlg3JF1m2-A |title=Há 13 anos, Vila Belmiro ganhava novas arquibancadas |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072315/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=22538#.Tlg3JF1m2-A |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} On January 27, 1998, during a game between Santos FC and Delia Tavano, a new illumination system was used, with level of 1,200 [[lux]], more than the [[FIFA]] minimum recommendation. [[File:Estádio Urbano Caldeira-2003-01-18.jpg|thumb|right|225px|Estádio Urbano Caldeira hosted a charity match in 2003.]] On November 17, 2003, Santos FC opened the ''Memorial das Conquistas'', a place inside the stadium as the club memorial, containing trophies, medals, documents, shirts, posters, movies and many other items that recount the club's history. Visitors can also enter the team clock room, press room and the pitch, and, at the end of a tour, can buy club products in a club store inside the stadium. In 2009, the new electronic scoreboard was purchased, twice the size of the previous panel, and provides the score of the game, shows materials, promotions and news of Santos. In addition, the stadium has acquired new seats. More than five thousand seats were installed to better serve members of the club. The seats have been approved by FIFA and were imported from Europe. The Vila Belmiro was one of the venues of the [[1949 South American Championship|1949 Copa América]],{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/49safull.html |title=Southamerican Championship 1949 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327093532/http://www.rsssf.com/tables/49safull.html |archivedate=March 27, 2009 }} hosted the [[1962 Copa Libertadores]] final and the [[1998 Copa CONMEBOL]] final.{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/copa62.html |title=Copa Libertadores de América 1962 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/sacups/conmebol98.html |title=Copa Conmebol 1998 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112145241/http://www.rsssf.com/sacups/conmebol98.html |archivedate=January 12, 2016 |df=mdy }} It has also hosted a [[Copa do Brasil]] final in [[2010 Copa do Brasil|2010]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssfbrasil.com/tablesae/cbr2010.htm |title=Brazil 2010 Cup |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese}} Due to its relative-low capacity, Santos has used other stadiums for high-profile matches such as the [[Estádio Palestra Itália]],{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/supcopa68.html |title=Recopa Sudamericana 1968 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/supcopa69.html |title=Recopa Sudamericana 1969 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} [[Estádio do Pacaembu|Pacaembu]] and [[Estádio do Morumbi|Morumbi]],{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70611 |title=O Santos FC e o Pacaembu |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909221306/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/colunas/conteudo.asp?id=70611 |archivedate=September 9, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/copa2011.html |title=Copa Libertadores de América 2011 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/copa03.html |title=Copa Libertadores de América 2003 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} all located in [[São Paulo]], and the [[Maracanã (stadium)|Maracanã]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]].{{cite web|url=http://rsssf.com/sacups/copa63.html |title=Copa Libertadores de América 1963 |publisher=[[RSSSF]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011}} Current Santos President Luís Álvaro Ribeiro and other club directors are agreeing on building a stadium in a city nearby Santos called [[Cubatão]], a stadium for 40,000 people which would become Santos' home field for almost 70% of the games during the season which would increase the team's profit. ==Memorial das Conquistas== [[File:Memorial SantosFC.JPG|thumb|right|Several trophies won by Santos FC at the Memorial das Conquistas]] Santos built a space to receive visitors and tourists interested in knowing the history and achievements of the club in 2003. Named the ''Memorial das Conquistas'',{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/clube/default.asp?c=O%20Clube&st=Memorial%20das%20Conquistas |title=Memorial das Conquistas |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111020200507/http://www.santosfc.com.br/clube/default.asp?c=O%20Clube&st=Memorial%20das%20Conquistas |archive-date=October 20, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} it is one of the main attractions of the Estádio Urbano Caldeira, inaugurated by [[Pelé]], [[Carlos Roberto Cabral|Cabralzinho]] and Marcelo Texeira.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=23575#.TlhceV1m2-B |title=Pelé inaugura espaço espaço no Memorial das Conquistas dedicado ao octa no Brasileiro |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072327/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=23575#.TlhceV1m2-B |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The museum's collection is distributed over an area of 380 square meters. In addition to trophies, there are life-size photos, banners, documents, uniforms, balls, and other multimedia objects. Visitors are greeted by bilingual guides, available to answer queries regarding the club's history and exhibits at the museum. The material is divided into thematic areas. Beyond ''Espaço Pelé'' (personal collection with pieces from ''O Rei''),Various from many of his biographies, See for example {{cite web|url=http://pele.m-qp-m.com/english/pele.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801150055/http://pele.m-qp-m.com/english/pele.shtml |archivedate=August 1, 2009 |df= }} 3rd section, last line: " 'The King' was given to Pelé by the French press in 1961 after he played a few matches with SFC in Europe" Or the already quote [http://espn.go.com/classic/biography/s/Pele.html] Or the book "Pele, King of Soccer/Pele, El rey del futbol – Monica Brown (Author) & Rudy Gutierrez (Illustrator) Rayo Publishing December 2008 {{ISBN|978-0-06-122779-0}} " there is the location of state and national titles, information about the city, Santos and the World, among others. The museum also innovates by presenting various multimedia equipment such as TV sets, which allow viewing of historical plays. The ''CineGol'' is a site, which reproduces a piece of football field in a projection room that lets you view movies and special clips about the club. Since its inauguration, it has received over 300,000 visitors.{{cite web |url=http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=17572#.TlhdUV1m2-B |title=Conheça o Memorial das Conquistas do Santos FC |publisher=[[Santos Futebol Clube]] |date= |accessdate=August 10, 2011 |language=Portuguese |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326072338/http://www.santosfc.com.br/noticias/conteudo.asp?id=17572#.TlhdUV1m2-B |archive-date=March 26, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ==1949 South American Championship== One match of the [[1949 South American Championship]] was played at the Estádio Urbano Caldeira: {{football box |date = April 27, 1949 |team1 = {{fb-rt|PER}} |score = 3–0 |team2 = {{fb|BOL}} |goals1 = [[Roberto Drago|R. Drago]] {{goal|31||74}}
[[Cornelio Heredia|Heredia]] {{goal|77|pen.}} |goals2 = |stadium = [[Vila Belmiro]], [[Santos, São Paulo|Santos]] |attendance = 12,000 |referee = [[Alberto Da Gama Malcher]] (BRA) }} ==See also== {{More references|date=September 2016}} '''Field house''' or '''fieldhouse''' is a common name for indoor sports [[arena]]s and [[stadiums]], mostly used for [[college basketball]], [[volleyball]], or [[ice hockey]]. Additionally it is known to serve as a support building for various adjacent sports fields, i.e. locker room, team room, coaches' offices, etc. When spelled "'''Field House'''", it may also refer to a residence owned by someone named [[Field (surname)|Field]].
This [[American English]] term dates from the 1890s.<ref>''[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/field-house Random House Dictionary]'': "1890–95, Americanism"</ref><ref>{{MerriamWebsterDictionary|fieldhouse}}: "First known use: 1895"</ref>
